  physical_appearance: The images present a series of five rectangular textile artworks
 placed side by side. They are mounted on a wall. All of the artworks have a similar border comprising of a black motif with red dots in the triangular
 heart
 and clubbed shape designs. The background of the artworks are yellow in colour. Each artwork depicts the outlines of two people standing side by side. They are holding hands and facing the viewer. All of them are barefoot. They are represented with ethnic costumes and headgears. Lao script has been embroidered on all five of the textile artworks.

  subject_terms_4: 

  sgcool_label_text: Phasao Lao’s History series is a rudimentary chronicle of his Hmong clan and its familial provenance. Each panel includes a black border of motifs that symbolise ‘spirits’
 and an outline of different ancestors or leaders in red
 the colour of strength and courage. But whereas oral and pictorial histories are more commonplace in Hmong culture
 Lao has embroidered Lao script onto the fabric
 placing significance on the posterity of both his artwork and his Hmong clan.

metadata.physical_appearance: The images present a series of five rectangular textile artworks, placed side by side. They are mounted on a wall. All of the artworks have a similar border comprising of a black motif with red dots in the triangular, heart, and clubbed shape designs. The background of the artworks are yellow in colour. Each artwork depicts the outlines of two people standing side by side. They are holding hands and facing the viewer. All of them are barefoot. They are represented with ethnic costumes and headgears. Lao script has been embroidered on all five of the textile artworks.

metadata.subject_terms_2: Motifs Embroidery, Hmong Hmong (Asian people) Ethnic costume Symbolism Appliqué Family histories
metadata.subject_terms_3: Ethnic costume Textile art and design Genealogy
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Phasao Lao’s History series is a rudimentary chronicle of his Hmong clan and its familial provenance. Each panel includes a black border of motifs that symbolise ‘spirits’, and an outline of different ancestors or leaders in red, the colour of strength and courage. But whereas oral and pictorial histories are more commonplace in Hmong culture, Lao has embroidered Lao script onto the fabric, placing significance on the posterity of both his artwork and his Hmong clan.
